snapshot.summary: Oregon's Renewable Portfolio Standard (RPS) establishes a minimum amount of renewable energy that must be sold by the state's large electricity providers. Small utilities, defined as those with less than 3% of the state's load, are subject to less strict standards. This page identifies and describes the features of the RPS and how they work together to define the minimum amount of renewable energy that will be sold in Oregon.
snapshot.policy_trajectory: Most states define a pathway to 'ramp-up' the amount of renewable energy that must be sold. This chart allows you to compare your state's policy pathway to its neighbors. Oregon's pathway is red. Click on another state to learn more about their RPS.
overview: 25% of the state's energy consumption must be from renewable sources by 2025
RPS requires a total of 20 MW-AC of solar PV by 2020
Utilities costs are capped at 4% of the utility's annual revenue requirement

legislation.statute: The RPS was established in 2007 as part of the Oregon Renewable Energy Act of 2007, Senate Bill 838. The purpose was to develop electricity procurement plans for renewable power. HB 3039, enacted in 2009, subsequently created requirements for utilities to develop a total of 20 MW of solar PV by 2020. Renewable energy may be bundled with RECs.

rps_tech_details.name: Eligible Technologies
rps_tech_details.description: Solar Thermal Electric, Photovoltaics, Landfill Gas, Wind, Biomass, Hydroelectric, Geothermal Electric, Municipal Solid Waste, Hydrogen, Anaerobic Digestion, Tidal Energy, Wave Energy, Ocean Thermal

rps_tech_details.name: Geographic Eligibility
rps_tech_details.description: Oregon does not specify geographic eligibilities in its RPS.

rps_tech_details.name: Technology Requirements
rps_tech_details.description: 20 MW sized 500 kW to 5 MW Solar PV by 2020.

rps_tech_details.name: Sectors
rps_tech_details.description: Municipal Utility, Investor-Owned Utility, Rural Electric Cooperative, Retail Supplier

rps_tech_details.name: Non-compliance Penalty
rps_tech_details.description: $50/MWh for 2011, to be re-established by October 1 each subsequent even-numbered year.

legislation.cost_cap_details: Oregon utilities are not required to comply with the RPS when compliance costs for the utilities exceed 4% of the utility's annual revenue requirement for that compliance year
legislation.carveouts: Utilites must develop 20 MW solar PV by 2025. This requirement does not correspond to the ramp-up schedule in its existing structure in the Oregon RPS. The solar capacity requirement is allocated among 3 utilities in Oregon as follows: PGE (10.9MW), Pacific Power (8.7MW), Idaho Power (0.5MW).
